title: 106_hr2100
content: The "Antitampering Act of 1999" prohibits unauthorized alteration of product identification codes under the Lanham Act. The "Antitampering Act of 1999" prohibits unauthorized alteration of product identification codes under the Lanham Act. Section 43A defines terms related to consumers and goods, specifying that a consumer is the ultimate user or purchaser of a good, excluding retailers, and a good includes articles produced for sale in interstate commerce. The term 'manufacturer' includes the original manufacturer of a good and their duly appointed agent or representative. The term 'product identification code' encompasses any number, letter, symbol, marking, date, code, software, or technology affixed to a good for traceability back to production details or critical data. The term 'Universal Product Code' refers to the bar code representing goods in retail applications, and 'value' means the greatest of face, par, or market value. It is prohibited to alter, remove, or conceal product identification codes without authorization. The prohibition includes altering, concealing, or removing product identification codes without authorization, as well as importing, exporting, selling, or distributing goods with altered codes. The prohibitions set forth in subsection (b) apply to product identification codes affixed to goods held for sale in interstate or foreign commerce. Retailers can use UPC codes or other legitimate pricing codes as long as they do not permanently alter existing product identification codes. The section allows distributors to repackage products for resale as long as the original product identification code is retained without any changes, and the distributor is registered with relevant agencies. The section permits distributors to repack products for resale if done in compliance with State and Federal laws. The term 'shipping container' refers to containers used for transporting products in bulk to manufacturers, packers, processors, or distributors, including retailers shipping to customers. Retail customers can receive containers and wrappings without printed matter related to specific products. Willful violations of this section may result in criminal penalties under section 1365A of title 18. Injured parties can seek civil remedies through a civil action in a US district court, including injunctions to prevent violations. The court can impound goods involved in a violation and order their destruction as part of a final judgment. The court can dispose of impounded goods that are not unsafe by delivering them to government agencies or charitable institutions with a need for them, as long as it does not violate the law and the manufacturer consents. In any legal action, the plaintiff can recover actual damages and the violator's profits from a violation. The plaintiff only needs to prove the violator's sales for profit calculation. Alternatively, the plaintiff can choose statutory damages before final judgment. Before final judgment, statutory damages can be awarded for violations under this section. The amount can range from $500 to $100,000 for each type of goods involved, and if the violation threatens public health and safety, the range is $5,000 to $1,000,000. In any legal action, in addition to damages, costs, and attorney's fees can be recovered. In addition to damages, a prevailing plaintiff can recover full costs and reasonable attorney fees. For repeat violations within 3 years, the court may award treble damages, up to 3 times the original amount. The court may reduce damages if the violator proves they were unaware of the violation. The Attorney General enforces this section. The Attorney General enforces this section regarding the adulteration of product codes. The heading for title VIII of the Act of July 5, 1946, is amended to include "ADULTERATION OF PRODUCT CODES". SEC. 3. CRIMINAL PENALTIES. Criminal penalties for tampering with product identification codes under the Trademark Act of 1946 include fines and imprisonment based on the value of the goods involved and the level of risk to public health or safety. Criminal penalties for endangering public health or safety include fines and imprisonment up to 10 years, with harsher penalties for serious bodily injury or death resulting from reckless actions. Repeat offenders may face double the maximum imprisonment term. In any prosecution under this section, the court may grant injunctions and impound goods involved in the violation to prevent or restrain the alleged violation. Upon conviction of a violation, the court shall order the forfeiture and destruction of goods involved, or deliver them to government agencies if deemed safe. The court may dispose of goods involved in a violation by giving them to local government agencies or charitable institutions, with manufacturer consent and the opportunity to reapply product identification codes. Amendment to Section 2320(f) of title 18, United States Code, includes criminal tampering with product identification codes under section 1365A.
